utterances: I think it won't stop or slow anything down.

I think that Iraq they're--Iraq is two parallel places, one inside the Green Zone, where there's a sort of different life that goes on despite the violence outside; the Green Zone, listeners may know, is the US-protected fortress in the middle of the capital that is the center for most administrative decisions.
And inside--I can tell you I was in the Green Zone today, and it was nothing like the world outside of the Green Zone.
And the deals are going on, the talks are going on, the diplomats are exchanging niceties, and the Iraqi officials are moving forward.
Borzou Daragahi of the Los Angeles Times speaking with us from Baghdad.
Borzou, thank you.
Always a pleasure.
And right now, the opinion page.
Sex scandals are infrequent but predictable visitors to our nation's capital.
At the moment, it's the case of the alleged madam who provided ABC News with a big, fat, little black book of her clients.
As licit Lily Burana put it in Washington Post editorial yesterday, you just can't top a Washington D.C.
sex scandals for spectator sport.
In her op-ed, the one-time stripper and army wife confessed that she's curious about the names of the rich and powerful men who show up in Ms. Julia's phone records.
But then on Friday night, ABC's 20/20 reported that there not rich and powerful enough to bother naming.
So, what is it about Washington sex scandals that intrigues?
Is this story something you've been following?
Give us a call, 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
You can also send us email - talk@NPR.org - or join the conversation on our blog and the find the link to the op-ed, NPR.org/blogofthenation.
Lily Burana is with us bureau in New York.
She writes the memoir ""Strip City: A Stripper's Farewell Journey Across America."" And it's nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
It's lovely to be here, thank you.
And apparently some of these men told their man that there were more important than it turns out that they are, so what's the world coming to you if you can't trust a john.

Well, I think it's must be something of a paradox for the clients in question, because on one hand they have the relief of being not important enough to be named on national television, but on the other hand they are not important enough to be named on national television, there's the rub.

There's also the shock horror that a Madam - an alleged Madam - is disclosing her client lists, as you note in your piece there's a sort of a mutual assured destruction that usually ensures discretion on both sides of this transaction?
Absolutely, I think it's understood among women who are in this line of work that pimping and pandering is a felony where it's being a service provider, or so to speak, is a misdemeanor.
So they're facing some fairly heavy charges in the events that they are caught and prosecuted.
And on the side of the costumers, certainly they are not looking to have their proclivities advertise that is part of the deal that struck.
The thing that is fascinating to me is how outrage women in the sex industry community and the general public are that this woman would threaten to name names.
I think it's very easy to have that fantasy of being loyal and discreet into death, until you are facing felony charges and potential prison time.
I think what we have here is a woman in a sinking rowboat and she's doing anything she can to bail herself out, a cup at a time.
Yeah.
She's a facing charges herself here in Washington that we should point out, she is based in California, in Vallejo, California, and was allegedly running this service.
Well, she was running a service, it's what it actually did is in dispute - but she was running this service virtually, phone and computer by - from California.
One of the ways that technology makes our life easier?
I'm sure there are many wives who are not particularly happy by this new technological wrinkle, however it is very it is very much the state of affairs, so to speak.

If you are not the service provider yourself, basically what you're doing is making connections between two people on the buying and selling end of the transaction - if I dare be so calculating and my description.
So, you're really - the woman doesn't need to be there.
I think it's probably more typical for a costumer to want to see with whom he's engaging, but that's not necessarily the way it's done across the board.
And you raised questions in your article about the media's easy description of this as a high-class escort service.
In fact, high-class escort services that charge considerably more than a 275, $275 to $300 an hour that these women where charging.
And Lily Burana, there is - again, you point out in your piece, there's an aspect of - well, what's the German word - schadenfreude, taking pleasure in the discomfort of others.
You can't help it.
It is my personal weakness.
It is my chocolate-dipped doughnut of morals, you know, just creepiness on my part.

I am as fascinated with this as the next person, simply because when you see somebody who builds their political house on this foundation of moral strength, infallibility, and then you noticed that it's, you know, toppled by their own actions - there's something so primally satisfying about that.
Yeah.
But, you know, on top of that, she didn't really come in with any foreign policy experience.
The Air Force started off as part of the Army a century ago.
Following its success in the Second World War, the Air Force became an independent branch of the military in September 1947.
Since then, air power has played a key role in military might.

The original dream of aviators as a war-fighting weapon that could go to the other side of the world quickly and then precisely take down an enemy without causing huge collateral damage has been realized.
Loren Thompson of the Lexington Institute says in the First Gulf War, the Air Force took the lead in defeating the Iraqi military.
The current war in Iraq, he adds, started off as an air campaign, but that didn't last for long.

Once the air power had worked its magic in terms of taking down the Iraqis, we then needed to occupy the country, put in a new government, and try to rebuild the place, and that is largely a ground force activity.
The Air Force is now 60 years old, and many of its planes are pretty old too, right?
The last time America modernized its air fleets in a big way was during the Reagan years.
There was a time then when we were buying over 200 aircraft a year for the Air Force, but that was a long time ago.
And in the intervening period, we have bought very few new aircraft.
As a consequence, the Cold War fleets of fighters, of bombers, of tankers, of other aircraft, has frankly grown decrepit.
And yet somehow the service can't seem to generate a sense of urgency about replacing these old aircraft in the political system.
If this doesn't start happening soon, there's going to be some doubt about the global air superiority of the United States in the future.
Why is the Air Force facing such resistance to get the funding for newer planes?
There are pressing needs in Iraq for more ground forces.
It's clear that it's not the Air Force that is being overstretched in Iraq - it's the Army and the Marine Corps.
Secondly, the United States has had global air superiority for so long that it's hard for many people to even imagine not having it.
The last time an American soldier was killed by a hostile aircraft was in 1953.
So trying to convince people that there's a danger we won't have air superiority in some time in the foreseeable future, that's not an easy thing to do.
So what does this look like for the future of warfare?
I mean, it seems as if the threat of terrorism isn't necessarily going away anytime soon, so what does the outlook look like for the Air Force?
The Pentagon is currently conducting an internal assessment of future war-fighting requirement.
And what that assessment tends to point to is that there will be a greater requirement for air power in the future, and probably a diminished requirement for ground forces.

As a general proposition, if you're going to be fighting an Iran or a North Korea or a China in the future, you're probably going to be relying a lot more heavily on air power than we are today in Iraq.
Why is that?
First of all, they will likely be state-based with very large military capabilities.
And secondly, the simple geography of a country like North Korea or China or Iran doesn't lend itself very well to relying on ground forces.
We don't have the kind of forces that would be needed to actually occupy the country, and so we must defeat them from the air.
So this month is the 60th anniversary of the Air Force.
Looking back over six decades, do they have cause to celebrate?
I think that the U.S.
Air Force has many reasons to celebrate.
The problem here is that we are facing adversaries for which the original aviators were not very well prepared and for which our technology today is not very well adapted.
And it's going to take some time for us to figure out how air power can most productively deal with things like terrorists and insurgents.
Loren Thompson of the Lexington Institute, thank you so much.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of song, ""The U.S.
Air Force"")
(Singing) And gave it to the men who proudly wear the U.S.
Air Force Blue.
Harvard is defending its admissions policy in court this week.
A group that opposes affirmative action has sued the school, saying it discriminates against Asian-American applicants.
Beyond grades and test scores, Harvard rates applicants on personality considerations.
And this lawsuit alleges that Harvard gave Asian-Americans lower personality ratings than other applicants, limiting the number of Asian-Americans who get in.
Sally Chen is a Harvard senior, and she's Asian-American.
She's part of a group of students scheduled to testify for Harvard at the trial.
Welcome.
Thank you so much.
I'm so happy to be here.
Tell me about what you plan to say when you testify at the trial.

I plan to speak very directly about how I really benefited by being able to talk about race and my being a Chinese-American from a working-class background, first-generation college student, how this was a really big part of my application and my personal statement.

I spoke very directly about how I played the role of translator and advocate for my family and for my parents and how that really developed my sense of social responsibility and my sense of wanting to do work that would have a contribution to my community and the people who need that the most.
How do you think Harvard's admissions policies helped you or affected you as an applicant to be a student?
When I was applying to college, I remember getting a lot of really confusing and conflicting advice.

I mean, for one thing, I think my counselor said people with higher scores don't get into Ivy League schools, really consider some backups and another counselor who said don't write an Asian immigrant story, don't write something that's already been told before, that's been heard before and isn't going to be compelling.
And I think those two things were really unsettling, I think, at the time to think that there was this idea that my story or my experiences would not be valued or would not be interesting.
And, you know, with scores that weren't valedictorian scores, it was a really tough bind to be in.
Despite that, I decided to speak most honestly about what made me who I am.
And when I viewed my admissions file - and my interviewers really kind of saw the value in the ways in which I was making these connections from my experiences to what I wanted to do.

I know as a op-ed person I'm supposed to be hovering ever so slightly above the news of the day, but I'll disclose and say that I have had friends who are escorts and in the early '90s in San Francisco which is not considered as affluent a city as D.C.
and it's environs - that was the going rates at that time.
And this was in the dates of grunge, so we're talking 15 - 16 years ago.

So a super sophisticated working girl will see that as a fairly modest sum and I think it's safe to say that a truly high-class dealing with the absolute top-flight executives, politicians, personalities, etc. - probably has many, many more systems of security in place in terms of avoiding disclosure.
I think that in - the likelihood is quite good that there would not be phone records to turn over if somebody really at the very, very top of the game were caught.
Mm-hmm.
And so perhaps the relative anonymity of the clientele reflects the sort of middle class surprises that are being charged?
Yeah.
We're not looking at women who are frisking in Hotel du Cap in the south of France.
We are looking at basic in-call, out-call, and of course it's scandalous because we're talking about a specific act that is considered taboo.
But in terms of the economies of scale, no, it's fairly unremarkable.
And we should point out, in her defense, this woman argues that in fact what she was providing was a sexual fantasy service.
If any sex actually happened, she is shocked, shocked that it actually went on.
Yeah.
Well, you know, I suppose when you're in trouble and your back's against the wall, you're going to offer any defense that you can to try to deflect the heat.
I don't know that anybody in the listening radius believes that she was providing a quote-unquote ""fantasy"" that didn't involve actual sexual contact between client and provider.
However, can we fault her for trying to offer that as a defense?
She has made a fair amount of noise about being also shocked - shocked - that none of her clients would come forward to defend the legitimacy of her business.
However, that is - it's simply ridiculous.

It's not part of the deal that is struck when one comes to an escort service where - whether it is sexual services you're purchasing or simply the pleasurable woman's company, you do not expect the pleasure broker is going to be able to call on - I mean, she's not going to be able to call on anybody to stand up for her.
Theâ€¦
Customer loyalty only goes so far.
